case_vignette: A 37-YEAR-OLD MAN COMES TO THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT WITH HIS WIFE BECAUSE OF A 3-DAY HISTORY OF SEVERE PAIN IN HIS RIGHT ARM. HE ALSO REPORTS THAT HE CANNOT MOVE HIS RIGHT ARM. THE SYMPTOMS BEGAN AFTER THE PATIENT WOKE UP ONE MORNING, HAVING SLEPT ON HIS SIDE. HE IS OTHERWISE HEALTHY. HE WORKS AS A WAITER AND SAYS THAT HE FEELS EXHAUSTED FROM WORKING SEVERAL NIGHT SHIFTS PER WEEK. HE ADDS THAT HE “CAN BARELY KEEP HIS EYES OPEN” WHEN LOOKING AFTER THEIR DAUGHTER THE NEXT DAY. SINCE THE ONSET OF THE PAIN, HE HAS BEEN UNABLE TO WORK AND IS FULLY DEPENDENT ON HIS WIFE, WHO TOOK AN EXTRA SHIFT TO MAKE ENOUGH MONEY TO PAY THEIR MONTHLY BILLS. THE PATIENT APPEARS RELAXED BUT ONLY ALLOWS HIMSELF TO BE EXAMINED AFTER HIS WIFE CONVINCES HIM. HIS VITAL SIGNS ARE WITHIN NORMAL LIMITS. EXAMINATION SHOWS 1/5 MUSCLE STRENGTH IN THE RIGHT ARM. REFLEXES ARE NORMAL. HE HAS NO SENSATION TO LIGHT TOUCH OVER THE ENTIRE RIGHT ARM AND FOREARM. WHEN A PIN PRICK TEST IS CONDUCTED, THE PATIENT RAPIDLY WITHDRAWS THE RIGHT ARM.
question: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS THE MOST LIKELY DIAGNOSIS?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have severe pain in my right arm and I cannot move it.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have been experiencing these symptoms for 3 days.
Have you had any recent injuries or accidents involving your right arm?
No, the symptoms began after I woke up one morning, having slept on my side.
Do you have any other symptoms, like numbness or tingling in your right arm?
Yes, I have no sensation to light touch over my entire right arm and forearm.
Have you experienced any muscle weakness or similar issues in other parts of your body?
No, the muscle weakness is only in my right arm.
Do you have any pre-existing health conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I am otherwise healthy and do not have any pre-existing health conditions.
Do you have a family history of neurological or muscular diseases?
I have not mentioned any family history of neurological or muscular diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Brachial Plexus Injury

The symptoms started upon waking up after the patient had slept on their side. There is no sensation to light touch throughout the entire right arm and forearm. The muscle weakness is isolated to the right arm only. The patient is otherwise healthy with no pre-existing health conditions and has not reported any family history of neurological or muscular diseases.
